Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platformS, into one of two Categories: Disagree and Agree. Classify the statement as "Agree" if no strong dissent is stated, otherwise classify it as "Disagree".

Comment: The key, defining London, is buried at the end, in half a sentence.

What MAKES it isn't cranes erecting buildings or old docks replaced by condos.

What makes London is this bit right here: "Its multiculturalism is astonishing".

Wait, what does that mean, "London's multiculturalism is astonishing", as distinguished say from that of some Canadian cities?

The answer: Close your eyes in London, listen to the middle aged people talk, their thick British accents, their dwelling mostly on everyday London street life, its beer and football. That is their culture, they are Londoners. 

Now open your eyes. 

Their skin is often dark brown, their facial features often Chinese in ancestry. But you could not tell that with your eyes closed listening to them. They're Londoners, THAT's their primary culture.

Not similar for some Canadian towns. Huge numbers arrive so fast from elsewhere, their languages and ways change towns 180 degrees. Close your eyes, listen. Where are you? Hard to tell...

Comment: Clearly this is where health care in the private sector would pay off. The cost to government would drop dramatically as it no longer would be paying for health care for those who can pay.  US data is useful. Pre Obama about 48 million Americans did not have insurance coverage. That is about 15% of the population, meaning that 85% of Americans can afford to pay for their health care. It is generally accepted that the US medical system, not health care system, is the best in the world. Thus one could expect to pay more than people in other countries.

 Canadians would select what level of care and thus cost that they want. On average it will probably be more than Canadians are paying now through taxes. However the quality of care would probably be higher.

Comment: I can illustrate one obvious reason why sexual assaults are under-reported.

It's an office Christmas party where alcohol is being consumed. A man into his cups suddenly grabs a co-worker's breast. That's a sexual assault under the Criminal Code. Will the victim of the assault press charges with the police? Most likely not. The man will be admonished by his co-workers and employer, and possibly lose his job. But few people in that situation, including the victim, want to see the offender receive a criminal conviction for his behavior.

By definition, the crime of sexual assault covers everything from the most horrific, violent attack on a helpless adolescent right down to the example I gave above. Yet many feminist advocates insist that sexual assault of even the most minor kind is misogynist and evil. And they've pushed society and its justice system in that direction. Until a more nuanced view of the issue comes about, sexual assaults will continue to be under-reported.

Comment: I teach at Horizon Alternative Senior School in Toronto. We have had a late start (9:45 am) for many years and it is the best decision we ever made. As the kids go through puberty and their sleep cycles naturally change, being at school on time and alert ready to learn before 9 am was a struggle. Tons of students were late and the scheduling had to be carefully done to ensure they weren't expected to do Math first thing in the morning - when most of them were still basically asleep. This was a particularly difficult problem for Horizon since we are an optional attendance school and many of our students commute fair distances to get to school. Changing the start time has been amazing. The students are on time. They are awake and ready to learn - no matter what the class on their schedule. They are happier. Science tells us this is a more natural cycle for adolescents and our experience proves that allowing for it makes a huge difference to school success.

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...

Comment: In Alaska, the resources belong to the people, which is why it makes sense for Alaskans to be paid, via the PFD, for the removal and sale of our nonrenewable resources. Another issue is the fact that eliminating the PFD hurts poor and middle class people worse than it hurts rich people, and that is wrong. Everyone should feel the pain equally when addressing our economic issues. We need to diversify our economy and we should be willing to pay for the services we receive: road maintenance, security, education, healthcare, etc. An income tax is the fairest and easiest way to make Alaskans pay for services while only charging them what they can afford. It is the easiest tax to set up and monitor and it would result in nonresidents who work in Alaska also helping to pay for those services. The first $25,000 should be untaxed for all Alaskans and then there should be a fixed, flat tax on all earnings above that (5%?) - no loopholes. Nonresidents should have to pay 5% on all earnings.

Comment: Exactly. Last time our building did special assessment we had older unit owners who had to sell. Imagine a huge sprinkler assessment's impact. I've heard it's as high as $15k, maybe more in some cases, but a great deal of variance can happen. I've heard a low of $3k-5k per unit. Note that many older condos have to deal with asbestos and other issues making the job not $3k-5k just for sprinklers. Asbestos abatement in my unit cost me over $3k just to scrape the ceiling, not replacing the finish. So that makes my ball park estimate about $10k or so per unit with finish coat and no drop down ceiling to cover pipes. And my unit was a smaller single bedroom one. I would encourage the city to give us a property tax credit, or funding resources and make sure we can confine the cost to sprinklers without triggering other code upgrades.

Comment: I was curious about this so I asked my own mortgage broker, who said: "I think they are missing the point if they pass this. It will not target the wealthy as much as it will target those in high cost areas." As I understand it from a recent DP article - http://www.denverpost.com/2017/11/03/how-many-people-have-half-million-dollar-homes/ - half a million here buys you a bigger-than-average home, but half a million in a place like San Francisco buys you one bedroom, one bath. So, it would seem, the "target" here is not so much "the wealthy," but where you live. And that is the subject of David Brooks' recent op ed titled "The Clash of Social Visions" - you can read it @ https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/06/opinion/republicans-taxes-cuts.html - The devil, they say, is in the details. And more often than not, those details are found in the fine print of the tax code.

Comment: In the area I live (Copper Basin), the majority of the trails where created by trappers and continue to be used by trappers. Some People recreating do find these trails and go down them, but most of them know the potential of traps being on the trail. Many trappers post the beginning of a trail as a trap line to warm people. Dogs do occasionally get into traps but that is because of irresponsible dog owners who allow their dogs to run loose from their properties. 

Our issues are different from a more urban area. The Board of Game should take up the issue by each game management  unit or area. That way public comment per area can be heard with the issues in each area. A state wide regulation is not fair to those of us that live in a more rural setting. Also local borough and city ordinance should be looked at for a urban areas with issues.

Comment: This is the first chance for immigration minister Hussen to put his stamp on the department and policy and he has done a decent job in that regard.

In this as in trade, taxation, regulation and most related matters, Mulroney set the economic agenda for Canada for 2 generations.

Comment: Lovely column, Margaret. Your experience with digital technology parallels my own and my wife's. I guess it's our age, Margaret.

BTW,  it's quite offputting to open up the comments section to Margaret's columns and find that there are consistently a number of people who are quite vicious in their remarks and mean-spirited  in their ad hominem  attacks and dismissive condescension. Not good for civil discourse.

Comment: I reply to my own post ---

Each action has consequences. The consequence of a legal abortion is the fetus. That such is 'murder', or that the fetus is a person, is contentious. Some consider it a sin. Some do not.

Illegal, back-alley, back-woods, second-story walk-up-clinic abortions have in the past, and will have in the future, consequences to indisputable living persons -- the women at risk in unsanitary conditions, the spouse if made a widower, the other children if rendered motherless, society in general if non-supervised teens roam streets. 

The potentially greater number of living persons affected as the result of illegal, unsanitary abortions is why I consider actions leading to such is the greater sin, and should be considered so even by those who believe abortion to be sinful.

Comment: I agree with you about the label 'populist': it's alarming the way that it is thrown at every oppositional voice or movement.  In fact, it's used so loosely that it simply means anyone who disagrees with neoliberalism and globalization.  Since I think that neoliberal policies and globalization were really set up to benefit global finance, 'populism' means anything that disagrees that the interests of global finance are the interests of the majority.  It's a dismissive term that fails any analytical test: populism simply means political movements that put 'the people' at the centre of analysis.  I ask myself: would Roosevelt's New Deal be considered part of a populist movement by today's supposed political establishment?  Would any political organization or movement that tried to help 'the people' be considered populist?  If so, then I'm a populist, although my politics are very different than that of Trump.

Comment: "Regurgitating talking points"...  I am a 59 year old lawyer.  When I started university in the humanities, a lot of it was simply paraphrasing the work of previous scholars (not unreasonable, if you are only 18 with only high school behind you).   Having said that, I was exposed to many different authors and many different ideas.  I suddenly became a much more aware and concerned citizen.  It broadened my interests and my love of learning new things took flight. 
In the current system I would never have become a lawyer.  Over time, the cost of education has increased exponentially and the rewards for such education have dwindled.  If someone had said to me, back in the 70's, "Hey, if you take an Arts degree you might get into law school but if your marks aren't good enough you will be a barista and owe tens of thousands of dollars in student debt",  I would never have done it.
Millennials need opportunity not obstacles.

Comment: Politicians can always be blamed. And in this case they deserve it for not doing something about the way judges have, over the years, made every aspect of the judicial system immensely expensive, complicated and time consuming. Cases which used to be done in a day now take weeks because of the absurd complexity of judge-written laws and procedures. A cop arrests someone for DUI can expect to spend the next several hours filling out multiple forms demanded by the legal system (I heard there were over a dozen that had to be filled out). Defense lawyers will pour over all these forms in the coming weeks looking for the slightest sign of a misstatement or pre-judgement or procedural error or, hell, a spelling mistake on which to launch complex judicial challenges. Everything will be challenged, including the blood test, the breathalyzer, the cop's judgement, and for all I know the air pressure in the tires. And that's one of the easier, less complicated kinds of cases.

Comment: The so called "clean energy" is not clean and is unable to provide energy when needed. The three main forms of "clean energy" are wind turbines, solar panels and biomass. Wind turbines only provide energy when there is the required amount of wind. When there is not enough wind or when there is too much wind, wind turbines do not provide any energy at all. However when they are providing energy, industrial wind turbines, most of which are 500 ft tall, kill birds and bats by the thousands. The manufacture of magnets for industrial wind turbines creates major pollution problems in China as does the manufacture of solar panels. Solar panels only provide energy when there is sunshine. Ground based solar panels require massive use of herbicides to suppress plant growth.  Wind and solar require large scale construction of power lines to connect them to the grid. Biomass is the burning of wood chips, currently supplied by cutting down forests. "Clean energy" is an environmental disaster.

Comment: It absolutely should not be dropped. Under our current system we have a Liberal majority government voted for by fewer than 25% of the eligible electorate, while 60% of that electorate showed up at the polls to actually vote against the government we have. This was also true of the previous Conservative government. It's been true of many other governments historically, which may explain why voter turnout is so low - the process is essentially a waste of time for the many people who live in "safe" ridings (i.e. ridings that are virtually impossible for other parties to win - so, for example,  if 60% of your riding is guaranteed to vote for a party you don't like, you might as well stay home rather than vote). 

It's been observed of some wealthy people who are now poor that they lost their money slowly at first, then all at once. The same can be said of democracy. Intelligent, well thought out, change is necessary to keep our democracy healthy.

Comment: There are basically two types of trappers in Alaska.
1) The first group are trappers who take their vocation seriously, and professionally. These guys (and gals) go out of their way to not catch dogs as well as maintain other ethical standards.
2) The second group it goes something like this: "I"m an Alaskan, it's my right to trap however I want to, it's my land, etc., etc.. These same "trappers" are the guys who happen to find a bunch of rusty traps, stop by Freddy's, pick up a trapping license, then go out and set traps hither-and-yon. These are the trappers who are causing the problems.
A simple solution would be to require anyone desiring to purchase a trapping license to first undergo and pass trapper training course. For starters that requirement would weed out a huge percentage of the casual wannabe trapper types. These are the ones causing the vast majority of the problems.

Of course this suggested solution won't satisfy the anti-trappers, but would help the current problem.

Comment: In 1883 the poem was written to raise funds for the statue.  It was engraved on a plaque and placed on the lower pedestal in 1903.  In 1903 there were roughly 80 million people living in the United (45) States and its territories.  Oklahoma would not be a state for 4 more years.
The automobile was certainly not a commonly used commodity, and there was virtually no transportation infrastructure.  Running water and electricity were practically non-existent in virtually every rural area.
There was virtually no national debt, unemployment was low, and there were no government welfare programs.  Immigrants had to rely on their own ability to earn incomes, support from family members and church communities, or a combination of both.
Since the United States has become a welfare state, way too many immigrants are coming here dependent on government handouts.  While we want to be a generous nation, we can't continue like this.  20 TRILLION in debt, not including 100 TRILLION in liabilities.

Comment: Unlike Canada, Denmark and the rest of the European Union have very strict vehicle third-party safety standards for all road vehicles. He should study hard so that he excels academically, make connections with his professors, take opportunities to hone his research and communication skills (verbal and written), seek out experiential learning opportunities (e.g. co-op, internship, lab/research assistant, TA), join clubs - both academic and social, attend conferences and symposiums, and actively network while rounding out his education in the arts/humanities/social sciences. If possible he should also consider studying abroad. Basically the same things he should do regardless of career focus. Certainly he needs to stand out academically, but there is more to being successful in a career than knowledge and technical expertise in one's field. It's just as much about who you know and what connections you can make. In order network he needs to be articulate and broadly educated in areas outside his field so that he can converse intelligently on a variety of topics. It's all about being able to market yourself.

Comment: I heard the 'bubble will burst' scare for the past 30 years, if not more. And it never did; there were some temporary price drops and demand swings, but nothing, that would alter the old real estate axiom: "prices will always rise on the long run, because the supply will always be limited".
All 3 levels of governments are complicit in what we see today.
The City administration should have NEVER allowed infills in established neighbourhoods without controlling (strictly!) what is being built to replace what was there before; no severing of a building lot to allow 2, or more structures to replace one.
The Provincial governments shouldn't have allowed creeping subdivision development gobbling up arable farmland.
And the Feds should have put rules and regulations in place long time ago, not by tweaking with mortgage lending, but rules with teeth, such as mandatory building starts within 2 years; vacant lodging tax; excise tax on foreign buyers; raising the capital gains tax.

Comment: The Ottomans did not make serious attempts to invade Western Europe. Their Sultan explicitly told Kara Mustafa not to invade Vienna, and if he attempted to do so, and failed, he would have to kill himself with  a royal cord. 

The Ottomans ruled over most of the former Roman Empire. In the Roman Empire, 9 of the 10 largest cities were in the Middle East and Turkey. Not in Western Europe. This has to do with the fertile soils of the Nile, Tigris, Euphrates, etc. Back then agriculture occupied 90 percent of the working population.

The increases of population in Europe were of the poor and starving. For example, the Irish left after the Potato Famine. It wasn't a sign of their success, but of their poverty and overpopulation.

In history, the poor have almost always emigrated to richer countries. That was the reason that hundreds of thousands of Brits went to India from the 16th to the 19th centuries. Same reason no Indians went in the other direction.

Comment: Jpg - That's a pretty misinformed statement.  The energy companies working oil shale claims in the 1970s had to file mining claims under the Mining Laws of 1872.  Under the old laws, if a person or company worked the claim for the statutory period, the received a patent (title) to the land from the US Gov (not land owned by ranchers).  This is why you find little slivers of private land all over Colorado's national forests; they were mining claims.   In the 1980s the system was being abused (ski towns) and the laws were changed so that fee title was no longer conveyed. 

It sounds like the ranchers were there permissively for years and were finally asked to actually sign a grazing lease.  She claims it is hers and says no.  So move your cows.

Comment: The question of buying a house depends on the market conditions. One has to consider the difference between rent + utilities and mortgage, utilities, insurances, taxes, and maintenance.

For example, rent: $800, and mortgage: $1200, but with other expenses, total cost: $1900.

Suppose that the house price is $270K, with $55K downpayment, and the price is appreciating at 5% annually. 

Suppose stock market is paying 10%, and mortgage interest rate is 3.5%

Over a 5 year outlook:
Net Worth with Stock Market = 80,500 + 109,904 = 190,404 - (15% capital gains) = 161K
Net Worth with House = $344,596 - 189,816 (remaining mortgage liability)  - Exit Costs (3.5%)= 142K

One of the things that is different with investment calculation today, is the leverage on the mortage. In a highly levered mortgage with low interest rate, the 5% appreciation is being earned on a very high principal amount. However, this is also a bubble situation, where incomes may not be sufficient to pay the future price.

Comment: A rail-funding bill is going to pass out of the legislature and go to the governor to sign. The question is how  the funding decision will affect Oahu residents. If the GET surcharge is extended to pay for the construction, most residents won't notice a difference. Things will remain the same as they have been for the past 10 + years (the GET surcharge began January 1, 2007).

If Matthew Johnson gets his way, the city will have to cut programs and services and raise property taxes, as well as other taxes and fees, to pay for the balance of work. In that case, residents will definitely notice a difference, a difference in their pocketbooks and in the quality of services provided by the city. They will also notice that the solution is not fair. 

Property owners will bear the lion's share of the cost. And tourists and others on temporary stays will pay none. Lower income residents, who will likely use rail the most, will not contribute either. Let's hope the legislature realizes this.

Comment: The problem lies in the significant gap between the tax rate of corporations and individuals. If a corporation is a "person" then it should be taxed as a person. If you take away the incentive for the loop hole, the loop hole goes away. 

The problem we have in Canada, and other wealthy nations, is that the money is increasingly being concentrated in the hands of a few, who fund elections and lobby governments for favourable loop holes that exacerbate the problem. It is an unsustainable situation that is either addressed through progressive public policy or pitchforks at the gates. 

We just experienced 10 years with a government who claims lower taxes makes it better for all. How many of you are better off now that you were 10 years ago? When the wealthy 10% can pay taxes at a rate of 15% or 20% and salaried workers pay 30% to 50% the system needs a reset.

Comment: Good article!

While it contained some interesting information on oil sands tailings ponds and abandoned oil wells in Alberta it seemed to gloss over the issue of abandoned mines in Ontario and Quebec.

Here's a couple of points from the MiningWatch Canada website:
-There remains over 5000 abandoned mines that have not been remediated in Ontario, many of them hazardous to the public, some seriously so!
-Ontario remains the only province in Canada with no Environmental Assessments required for large mines!

For a very interesting take on this issue I'd suggest watching the documentary "The Hole Story" , lots of information and graphic images of mines and tailings ponds in Quebec and Ontario. Just google "National Film Board The Hole Story" and you'll find a link that will take you directly to the documentary. Grab a coffee and enjoy the 1 hour and 20 minute show!

Comment: "Removing the exemption would hurt the city’s housing market by causing landlords to sell off their properties to avoid losing money on their investments, said Mr. Chong of the Greater Toronto Apartment Association."

This is just untrue. As a landlord the value of my rental property investments use 2 measurements. The overall gain in equity from a rising market and from paying down the mortgage. The 2nd is rental income minus expenses. So if property values rise more quickly then rents can the investment is still profitable even if a share of the new equity value has be rolled into covering expenses like increasing condo fees or building upkeep in the case of a conventional duplex conversions.

Comment: May I offer a few suggestions:
- The Office of Elections should send every registered voter a mail-in ballot. My wife and I are enrolled to automatically receive mail-in ballots each election. It allows to us review the ballot at our own pace, do some research and make an informed choice.
- Expand the number and duration of early voting sites, for people who prefer to vote in person. For instance, set up a site in each county council district (at a mall or someplace with ample parking) and operate them for three weeks prior to Election Day.
- At a future date, keep the early voting sites in operation through Election Day and eliminate the current system of 247 precinct voting sites. The large number of precinct sites makes for a lot of moving parts, increasing chances for error, insufficient staffing, ballots delivered to the wrong site, etc.

Comment: In none of the countries who beat us in health care - none - is it illegal to offer private insurance. Not one. 
Nevertheless the columnist still manages to slip in his own illogical bias against private health care. Sure, we're #1 in administration. Because we have to be. When you're waiting 2 years for a joint replacement everything has to be in place when you actually get there, so blood tests, imaging, preoperative assessments, anaesthesia consultations all have to be spot on when the day actually comes. And when it comes, guess what? Our care is as good as anywhere in the world. But to jump from that to the blithe statement that these achievements are due to our wonderful one-payer system is nonsense.  And is it any surprise that our seniors have above average numbers of chronic illnesses at any one time? They are all on waiting lists, from joint replacements to kidney transplants to cataract surgery to assessments for diabetic care. They are diagnosed - then the waiting begins.

Comment: The headline and the article seem to be two different things.  Rather than "remain firm", my suggestion to the Canadian government would be more along the lines of "keep your mouth shut and be adaptable".  In some ways the US is just catching up to Canada's protectionist attitude.  Canada has long been a lousy free-trader when it comes to areas like medical services, agricultural products, or simply subsidizing favoured businesses with government grants.  And the US has tired of being the market for all of the worlds cheap goods.  But as the playing field shifts, we are still in the best position to take advantage of the US market, especially if we keep our mouth shut and don't get all preachy about our neighbours.  
And with regard to Russia's President Putin, who I'm no fan of, Trump has simply looked on the store shelves to see whose products are putting Americans out of work, and decided it would be better for the US to be friends with Russia, and enemies with China.

Comment: I have climbed the Haiku Stairs twice.  Let's be quite clear, this is not for everyone.  That there have not been any major accidents - well, Thank God.   If the Stairs were re-opened:

1.  There has to be a control regarding the physical fitness of the people who would be allowed to use the Stairs.   Proper attire - primarily footwear - is a must; e.g., rubber slippers are dangerous, in this case.
2.  Better control of when the Stairs can & can't be used.  The stainless steel ladder can be shrouded in the clouds or rain making visibility almost nil, and the rails of the ladder quite wet & slippery.  Also, it can become quite chilly.
3.  "Does the City & County want to invest funds to make the Stairs safer?"  I would guess, in light of the overruns in the mass transit, that the answer is, "No!" 

Sections of the Stairs are attached to the Pali face; vertical & 100's of feet above the ground, with no safety net.  The potential for danger is there.   How to improve & better control?

Comment: My late father wanted to stay in the house on the property that had been in the family for more than 150 years.  His annual retirement income was under $20,000 a year. My brother, who is very careful with his money, advised him to take out a reverse mortgage to undertake some important renovations to support my father staying in the home.  

The reverse mortgage worked out very well.  Dad lived in the house for 15 years and had his wish to die at home come to fruition. When the estate was settle each of the 8 children received a small amount of money and the mortgage was paid off.

I am not sure if it is a good tool for middle age families who have become home rich but cash poor but certainly for many seniors on very fixed incomes it can be an important tool for maintaining independence.  Count me as a strong supporter of reverse mortgages!

Comment: The whole premise of the scientific argument is that genetic predisposition drives aptitude and interest and that this aptitude and interest are what determines career choices. This is a fallacy. Since innovation and creativity are best at the intersection of disparate disciplines, it may be better is someone who isn't inclined to a certain discipline to  pursue it, in order to bring a different point of view. For example as counter intuitive as it seems, introverts make the best sales people. Why, because being a great sales person is about listening and not talking and introverts are better listeners than extroverts. All that we get when we encourage folks to pursue what the seemly have a predisposition to is boring sameness.

Comment: Funny you should ask what folks see in rear view mirrors. It feels like Alberta conservatives believe they can bring the journey to a halt, turn it around, and go back to 2004.

It brings to mind a tender children's book called "Annie and the Old One." A child is trying to sabotage what her grandmother seems to know is the approach of the end of her life. "You cannot stop time," says the old woman to her granddaughter. 

So, one wonders what there is in the desire to unite the right other than a conviction among right wingers that they deserve to be in government because ... well, because they just do! 

There do seem to be two underlying questions, though, and it would be useful to see some thoughtful reflection on them:

It's better to go through hard times by cutting taxes, or
It's better to go through hard times by protecting government services, schools, health care, etc.

Comment: A typical out of touch view from a retired oilman. What Canada really needs is to strike a sane balance between the hard nosed environmentalists and the oil & gas industry. Those arguing that wind and solar are too expensive and not technologically viable haven't done their homework. PPAs locked in for 25 to 30 years are being signed today for less than $0.03 per kWh. Have a look at your power bill and see what conventional technologies are costing you. That doesn't mean we can easily go to 100% renewables (there are real challenges to manage intermittent sources) but going from 1.5% to 30%-40% can be done extremely economically even considering no additional technological improvements. On the transportation side, reducing emissions is even easier. Many of the largest auto makers no longer believe they will manufacture combustion engines for light vehicles after 2025. Canada needs a healthy energy sector, but I'm not optimistic if leaders like Gwyn bury their head in the sand.

Comment: The larger problem being ignored or elided is that Norwegian culture in general, and Norwegian criminal culture in particular, like that of most of the Scandinavian countries in particular and of Europe in general, has almost nothing in common with the US in important ways.

You simply cannot look at surface economic similarities and generalize that to facile equivalencies among deeper cultural values. Culturally homogeneous ancient states, like those of Scandinavia until very recently, have little in common with young heterogeneous countries like the US, as our crime statistics have consistently shown over the past century.

This has nothing to do with laws nor correctional philosophies, as both are downstream of culture. You cannot simply cut and paste laws and policies evolved to work within a given cultural milieu and drop them onto an entirely different circumstance and expect them to work.

Comment: The Canadian forest industry, particularly that of BC, has a great future - in the United States. BC's supply of timber has been significantly reduced by the pine beetle. In addition, it has some of the highest logging costs and is under constant pressure from the environmental lobby. By moving operations to the American south, BC forest companies are able to avoid tariffs and duties, operate their mills at far higher margins and obtain ready supplies of timber from both public and private sources. The days of using these companies as instruments of social policy are over given that the provincial government's power to reduce allowable cuts is now academic. By ignoring the advice of the industry at the outset of the beetle plague, the NDP doomed the BC forests and precipitated the move southward of it's industry's capital.. The tariffs and duties are simply the coup de grace.

Comment: when you say there isn't much one corrupt government can do, that many private solutions can't do better I disagree.  A privately administered program is always going to be more efficient and less bureaucratic than a government program - I get that.  But a private insurer is not looking after your best interests, because they are looking at the bottom line FIRST.  The decision is always whether to cover you or to make more money for the insurer, and I wonder which decision they always make ?  They're not there for you, they're there for THEM.  It's a business calculation for insurers at a time when all you want is to receive healthcare that you pay for, and its a totally dysfunctional system that is pretty much exclusive to our country.  It doesn't work.

Comment: A great deal of our present, internal, corruption and dysfunction in State gov't, flows smoothly under the same bridge - internal rules to insure correct and accountable behavior by gov't officials and function are routinely ignored when it suits.
Before changing the rule{s} though, we should ask "why" the rule in the 1st place?
In this case the answer appears to be that the rule is to insure than "the opposition" - dissenters, non-caucus, 'the other' party, outsiders - Any *opposition*, has time to participate and their voice heard,  Regardless of who/what the opposition is, and who the majority.  
Our legislature has become increasingly exclusionary, not only insisting that majority exclusively rules, but also frequently limiting the presumed minority's ability to participate in an meaningful, informed manner.  In other words, "Winning" has become more important than engaging in the fair and democratic practices that the 'rules' encourage.

Comment: A counter-argument. What if nuclear weapons, in a few hands, are actually a geopolitical stabilizing influence and a deterrent to large-scale conventional conflict?

The nuclear age arrived at the end of WWII. There hasn't been a large-scale conflict since. The reason why seems clear: a large-scale conflict will almost certainly lead to the use of nuclear weapons, which in turn means the end of human civilization.

Try as we might, humanity does not yet seem capable of resolving all conflicts without the use of deadly weapons. So if we're going to have such conflicts, then having some influence that keeps those conflicts on a smaller scale could be a good thing.

Comment: I am a Democrat, but I am an even stronger supporter of Governor Walker.  The Governor's reduction in the Permanent Fund dividend is part of a larger package of reductions - including reduced oil tax credits.  Declining oil production and low oil prices present real difficulties in meeting our operating budget.  We need to move beyond a single source of revenue for government.

For many Alaskans, the Dividend is an income supplement.  Cuts to services effect us all and a reduction in the PFD is certainly less regressive than a state sales tax as the primary revenue source.

We can no longer turn to oil revenues to fully meet our budget needs - the markets are too volatile and surpluses will last into the foreseeable future. 

The proposed law suit does not educate the public on the complexities of Alaska's revenue problem and discuss realistic solutions.

I am willing to be part of the solution if it is a reasonable and balanced approach.  A cut in the PFD is reasonable.

Comment: As a kid, I always thought it was awesome to go to the houses with decorated yards. Graveyards, webbing and other spooky stuff. Flashing light simulating science experiments inside, or blacklights. One house close by would take their garage and make a mini haunted house. It wasn't hard hearing sounds of chains, footsteps, creaking doors, screams, sadistic laughs and such while walking around the neighborhood. It seemed like most houses had carved pumpkins and got into the spirit, even if it was only window decorations. About 6 of 10 homes had lights on and candy to give. Topping it off was coming back home to hot chocolate or apple cider with a candy apple.

I don't want to deprive my children of a similar experience. The senses are stimulated, and there's a side benefit to them interacting with neighbors, with us present, in my opinion.

The mazes and patches, really, could be done anytime. The problem, as seen with some streets now, is having 2 out of 10 homes lit. Spirit is lacking.

Comment: No one familiar with the facts of limits to growth said every drop of oil would be gone by 1990.

In reality, petroleum geologist  M. King Hubbert predicted peak around the turn of the century, not complete depletion.

Peak means more than there ever was - or will be again.

It's like climbing to the top of a tall mountain - it's a great view, but you can't get higher up.

Fracking is near or at its peak, now, due to debt and depletion.  Geologist Art Berman says fracking is not a revolution, it is a retirement party.  

The US is not a net energy exporter.  We import lots of crude oil from the Middle East, West Africa, Venezuela, Canada and other places.  (We export a small amount of refined gasoline.)  We import  natural gas via LNG and pipelines from Canada.  

Denial is a renewable resource!

Comment: The term opiod epidemic is, in my opinion, overly broad.  It should not conflate all opiods as being equal and all users as being equal in their usage.  In the economically depressed region of Appalachia it is easier to get opiod pain medication on the "street" than it is any other drug.  There, it is the drug of choice out of convenience.  On the other hand, I regularly see injured workers managing pain on two 5mg vicodin a day, that their condition is chronic does not make them addicts. 

Do prescribed opiods pose the risk of addiction?  Yes.  However, I don't think  there is any medical evidence to support the notion that short-term pain (let's say 10 days or less) treated with opiods results in addiction.

Comment: There's no one that is more conscious of the catastrophic outcome of an airliner crash that the people who fly them. As such, pilots and their employers go to great lengths to reduce ALL the risk factors that could impact safety. And you don't have to browbeat anyone over the issue. It's the culture in aviation, and people are all over it. That's why flying is such a safe mode of travel.

But like some other aspects of life, safety isn't black and white. It resides along a continuum. If one insists that there be zero risk to safety in aviation, then no aircraft will ever leave the ground. It would mean, for example, that passengers would have to be immobilized and caged in their seats so that they couldn't get up and interfere with the flight.

The people who regulate and work in aviation operate according to the principle that it must be sufficiently safe, not perfectly safe. They base any concern about safety on actual facts and statistics, not sensationalism and fear.

Comment: Mr. Quilter presents some reasonable thoughts and ideas.  First, of course, he's quite correct, Eugene, like most American urban areas, is dominated by a private automobile culture. Eugene has worked hard to encourage alternative modes of transportation..primarily bicycles and public transit.  They still account for only a rather small percentage of individuals' movement in the area.  Each has serious limitations. 

Mr Quilter mentions "nodal" development as a possibly helpful alternative.  I agree.  I'm not sure how it's working, but the Crescent Village area concept is an example of such an attempt.  As we've seen over the years, automotive movement in the Eugene area is getting more and more difficult and they're no easy solutions.  Portland, Seattle, L.A. in our future?  Could someone who lives in the Crescent Village area comment.....

Comment: 2. Both Matthew and Luke shape their respective images of Jesus to distance him from the allegation that he was, in fact, a rebel, and also seek to clarify the relationship between Jesus and John. By the time Luke-Acts is written, there is a "standard" portrayal of Jesus as an exclusively spiritual Messiah who was misunderstood by -- everyone. But there remains this persistent tradition visible within the gospels in which both men are followed by militants, both men die accused of or associated with rebellion, and both men remain more or less enigmatic figures for at least several centuries.

Please understand: I am not prepared to argue that Jesus was, in fact, a Zealot or something of the kind. The Synoptic evangelists (especially Matthew) would have had a vested interest in portraying Jesus as having fulfilled the requirements for a Messiah, and would have had to walk a fine line between myth and reality.

Comment: As a primary care physician, I had a similar experience as the doctor in this story except I gave up on private practice to join the IHS. Electronic health record(EHR) did not help but decreased our productivity and made us more distant from our patients. It did improve my handwriting......I have mastered now 3 different EHRs and they all do the same: decrease productivity(for primary care), create a barrior between dr and patient and are frought with errors. Most are hard to read as drs tend to put too much into the visit report that is unnecessary or redundant to save time(recopy what was in a previous visit). 
    There is a great deal wrong with the American healthcare(dieasecare) system but I'm not sure a single payer system will fix it. A system where a dr is constantly worried about getting sued drives costs up.

Comment: Wolf Eagle, you are way off track. See my other post as to why many areas restrict harvest to full-curl rams. "Any sheep," "any ram," and "any ram with at least 3/4 or 7/8 curl" hunts used to be more common in Alaska, but now most areas restrict harvests to full-curl rams. Hunting needs to be limited for several reasons, primarily because it is popular (i.e., many hunters apply for permits), nobody wants to see too many hunters chasing a small number of legal sheep, and because sheep hunters (and sheep watchers) would like to see more sheep in the mountains, not less. We used to have hunts specifically for ewes in the Chugach Mountains, but they had to be suspended about 10 years ago because the number of sheep started to decline precipitously.  Not because of the hunting, but for the reasons mentioned in the article. No one hunts ewes for their horns. Finally, most sheep hunters are not wealthy. The local Dena'ina prized sheep meat and subsistence hunting is still practiced in Alaska.

Comment: Another source of difference between the NHPI and the Teranet HPI is that only the latter includes prices of condominium apartments. (The NHPI may contain prices of condominium row houses.) This will only improve the housing coverage of the CPI when it is included in that series. Since nothing has been published for it, it is still some way off. Comment: Mr Todd, There is not a justified aquifer contamination argument. This really does not have any scientific support.

Have you read Dr. Thomas's papers about the age of water in aquifers (and how water is filtered throughout the system, and how many toxic elements are naturally eroding into the system, then filtered or diluted in a HUGE aquifer system)? The tradewind inversion is usually capped at 9,000ft on Mauna Kea. 80-200inches of rain occurs per year below that line throughout different broad areas on Hawaii Island. This is where the aquifer recharge occurs, not the summit of Mauna Kea. 10-20 in. of rain is what typically occurs above 9000ft. In Dr. Thomas's studies, the age of the water in the aquifer is ~9,500 years old. It will take thousands of years (and major filtering and chemical interactions) as the water moves down to ~3,000ft on Big Island toward the aquifer if it ever makes it down from the summit. It will also be vastly diluted by water from below the cloudline.

Folks need to learn to adjust retirement expectations to appropriately factor these new realities, rather than whining and crying foul about some sort of nefarious schemes perpetrated by central banks to "steal their retirement interest savings"... that's all I have to say.

Comment: As a former Protestant Pastor, I went through a thorough vetting. The process was background and psychiatric examination to just become a candidate for ordination. Then I was what was called in care process for at least one year. During the in care process, the authorizing group could drop the candidate for any or no reason.  During this process, similar to a student teacher, I was observed and would communicate with the ordained pastor at least weekly. At this point, if any information came forward from anyone and there were questions, the candidate would have to answer the questions before the authorizing group. If they felt there were allegations, then the candidate would have to answer further. The questioning could head into any direction and so the candidate had to become like recent U.S. Supreme Court Justice Candidate. Don't say too much! I would ask anyone what's the basic outline for priest candidates. This particular story still has many questions left unanswered.

Comment: On a complex issue such as housing affordability, any claim that there's just one cause just one solution is suspect. The proponent likely has an interest in his particular solution. Supply, demand, speculation, lending policies all played a part. Prudent changes could reduce the excesses in the next cycle. 
The search for solutions becomes part of the hysteria that sets in as the bubble reaches its bursting point. Buyers get desperate for their last chance to buy, lenders allow them to borrow far more than is wise, sellers relish even higher prices next year. Profits are made until the bubble pops and suddenly a large portion of the presumed value evaporates. We've been here before.

Comment: Nope. It does not account for repeated back-and-forth passes. I just tested it. The sensor is not built in to the post that displays the count. There are two separate sensors that are in the ground, and they are about 60 feet away from the post. Look for the two small green plastic manhole-type covers directly next to the edge of the bike path. Those are the sensors. Like I said, there are two of them, arranged in the area where the bike path splits, forming the grassy triangular area. One lap around the triangle adds two "cyclists" to the count that is displayed on the post. So no, this contraption is not going to provide any realistic cycling data. It's bogus.

Comment: I see.  I have always found percentage confusing when used in such constructions.   From your comment, I suspect that you interpret 126% higher to mean that the tech wage is 226 percent of the average wage.  So Y is X % higher than Z means Y= ((X+100)/100)*Z.  Is this what you mean?  So 45K * 2.26 = 102K, which is close to what the reporter gave as the average tech salary.

All this is well and good.  But my essential point was that I do not believe the given average tech salary for a minute.  Having worked in tech all my life, the manufacturing operators and such who comprise so many of the tech workers tend to earn about 15-20/hour, far less than 105K/year.  It may be that the average tech salary is inflated by the incomes of the extremely rich company owners.  Perhaps the reporter should give the median tech income to tell us what the typical tech workers make.

Comment: I am facing this decision in the next few months. I am 66 years old with a non-indexed defined benefit pension.

If take the commuted value I can shelter most of it and take advantage of the low interest rate environment which will require my employer to give me a larger amount .

The downside is that this will make my RRSP/LIRA far too large and I have to be careful not to have a massive amount left in registered accounts when I die because that would be taxed at a maximum rate of 53.5%. Fortunately my spouse is still alive meaning that the tax problem will not arise until the second of us dies. 

If I keep the pension it will be cut by 40% upon my death.

I am leaning toward  taking the commuted value and if interest rates rise I will consider an annuity for an assured income stream.

Comment: To be clear here:  the attorneys for the State of Oregon were the defense attorneys in this trial.  They were not prosecuting crimes and they were not in the role of an assistant district attorney.  They are employees of the Department of Justice and they are responsible for defending the State of Oregon and its employees in civil litigation.  Their job was to produce a verdict for the state or to keep the damages low.  They did not accomplish any of their litigation objectives in this trial and made the office of the Attorney General look pretty bad.  I'd be there are some reprimands or lack of promotion as  result.  Much like in the case of Clevenger vs. U of O, the defense bar was overwhelmed by extremely competent civil rights lawyers not afraid to sue the state in Federal Court and then try the case on liability and damages.  "We the People" have a friend in Judge McShane.

But it is a bit of a stretch to call this a "lie." The POTUS has never been the one who decides who does and does not get to "keep their doctor." For nearly 50 years that has been solely up to the private, for-profit insurance companies (who literally do utilize death panels). It was similar to declaring what the weather will be like on a particular date three months from now. Nobody can do that with any certainty. That said, while it wasn't technically a lie and it is always blown way out of proportion, it was a foolish thing to say.

Comment: So what if you or your ancestors were immigrants?  It’s no excuse for immigrants to come here and abuse Canada’s generosity, or for Canadian politicians to have allowed it to happen at the expense of Canadians.  Getting really fed up with the "we're all immigrants" argument.

I am an immigrant since I moved here from a different country.  But I immigrated to a society built by others already here, which provided me with a heavily subsidized education, my family with a health care system, roads, etc.  Because of benefits available to me from living in this ready-made society (not on a homestead where I had to clear land), I have also become a contributing member of society. 

The argument “I built it” is stronger than “I found it first”.  For that reason, I am an immigrant grateful for the society built here by those who came to Canada before me, whether 300 years ago, or 20 years before me.

First Nations came here from elsewhere too, just earlier than the Europeans.

Comment: This problem has been developing for a long time. The first question i asked Prime Minister Trudeau Sr. back in 1978 was about how an aging Canada could finance its social programmes in the 21st century. The last act I took as an MP in 1988 was to get agreement for the Health and Welfare Committee to study financing Medicare in the 21st century. The report was long and thoughtful; but led to no major change.

Our current Medicare system is not serving us well. At least, the current government's proposals to devote more to home health care and mental health care are promising initiatives. But, my experience in Parliament as well as long service on a large hospital board have led me to conclude that our healthcare system needs to be reformed. Increasing the roles of highly trained nurse practitioners to ease the financial costs should be brought in.  

The solution is not just to "throw more money" at the current system; it is to restructure the system to do more with comparable money.

Comment: S P R I N G
                         by Mary Oliver ©

Somewhere
   a black bear
         has just risen from sleep
              and is staring

down the mountain.
    All night
         in the brisk and shallow restlessness
             of early spring

I think of her,
     her four black fists
          flicking the gravel,
                her tongue

like a red fire
   touching the grass,
        the cold water.
            There is only one question:

how to love this world.
      I think of her
           rising
               like a bland and leafy ledge

to sharpen her claws against
      the silence
          of the trees.
               Whatever else

my life is
    with its poems
          and its music
               and its glass cities,

it is also this dazzling darkness
   coming
         down the mountain
                breathing and tasting;

all day I think of her –
     her white teeth,
          her wordlessness,
                 her perfect love.

Comment: When I started teaching there was a class next door with learning disabled young children. They were given training and I recall letter formation and reversals were remediated.  There was a couple of classes in the system.  Within five years, those classes were replaced and more specific visual and auditory learning disabilities (memory & discrimination).  One previous poster mentioned that dyslexia is just one category that is language based.  I agree.  Dyslexia term has not been used in diagnosis or treatment in school systems for a reason.  WISC is the testing application to get an idea about the learning disabilities by someone trained in the testing using WISC ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wechsler_Intelligence_Scale_for_Children).  It was often given before the more expensive/intensive testing over several days by pyschomotrist.  Testing and application have improved over the 1960's misuse of the word Dislexia.

Comment: The BATF in 2015 considered banning certain types of 5.56 X 45 ammunition, currently used by all our armed forces in M16 service rifles and their military and civilian variants. The armor-piercing round under consideration was the M855 "green tip" ammunition used primarily by the marine corps and at least until recently available for purchase by civilians. I don't know what happened with that ban, whether it went into effect or not. To my knowledge hunting ammunition isn't under consideration for a ban, though I think most high-powered hunting bullets would penetrate Kevlar armor.

Game hunting has many advocates among sports retailers, guides, the tourist industry, and wildlife management agencies. Big game bullets are carefully engineered and manufactured to kill quickly, and those characteristics make them able to penetrate heavy bone while deforming in a controlled manner. The point is, that design is crucial to relatively humane hunting.

Comment: Sorry to say, but your attitude is one of the greatest causes of our deteriorating oceans.  The ocean is not so huge that what we do has no effect.  By the year 2100, the lifetime of a child born today, oceans will be 20 feet deeper and most probably beyond the ability to support life.

The ocean supplies 50% of the oxygen on earth, yet dissolves 35% of the Co2 produced, leading to acidification.  That means that by 2100, the oxygen generated may be reduced by 50%, contributing to a faster Co2 cycle.

To date, several of the species that you may have observed in tidal pools in 1970, no longer exist.  In the next 10 years, we will lose more species, than we have lost in the past 100 years.

The largest threat to our oceans; oil.  Not oil lost in ocean based spills, but oil lost on land and washed to the ocean.

Please take your children to see the tide pools, because they will be dead before your grandchildren see them.  We live in a golden age, our children do not.

Comment: There are several alternatives that are profitable to clear cut logging.  Selective logging is one.  Hemp can drastically reduce the need for wood and takes only FOUR MONTHS on 2 acres to grow enough to build a 1,200 square foot home, not 50 years.  Hempcrete is the product.  Hemp grown for dual or triple cropping.  The fiber for building material, the oil for food and plastics, insulation and more. The logging industry pays very little to no timber harvest taxes and they also pay nothing for the damage done to the watersheds, wildlife, wildlife habitat, loss of carbon sequestration, etc.  
The old, tired argument; "You live in a wood house, blah, blah, blah" is ridiculous.  It's like arguing against stopping whaling because people use the oil to light their homes.  We hare alternative materials and methods for logging.  It's WAY past time to look at all the externalities clear cut logging affects and hurts and make the industry pay for ALL the damages their practices create and stop.

Comment: I think the issue here is a question: what is the difference between a humane approach to complex issues and an endorsement of the status quo? Some of us think the gospel requires us to err on the side of compassion, others that the same gospel requires us to set limits for human behavior, and still others something in between. 
I don't think any one side is responsible for all the fear. I think "fear" is what we call the other side's insistence on their own positions. The underlying problem is, the gospel often gives us guidelines, not specific answers to specific issues.

Comment: Great story !
I really think more programs like this across the state would benefit many students.
There are not the same opportunities now days for youth to learn job skills and develop good work ethics as there was 30 years ago. Youth no longer deliver newspapers or sell them on the corner. At least not in our community. Three of my six kids started delivering the morning paper at 4:00 am, rain, snow or sleet. They started at the age of 9 and kept it up until they were 14 and could get retail service jobs. As a result, the grew up to be responsible adults with excellent work ethics. 
The customer service skills will help them not only at "work" but in real life situations.
Great teachers use programs like this to teach multiple subjects. Math, spelling, "science", chemistry, health and even about the laws or rules for running a commercial kitchen.

Comment: Manual Dexterity is not linked to intelligence, but reaction and processing time is. 

PET scans of people involved in abstract reasoning tasks show that the brains of high function folks use less energy, find a solution with less "work" than people who do poorly. Optimal brain processing works hand in hand with getting to the result faster. Tying involves converting text, spoken language, or thought to hand and finger movement.

The other highest IQ person in my class got higher rates than me because she was willing to make mistakes and correct them manually with ribbon or whiteout, a common practice back in the 1960s. 

I got a slower rate because I preferred accuracy over speed. I would rather get it right the first time than go back and fix it. Ah, the joys of ancient one off hard copy technology.

2.  Indian people were not citizens until 1956.

3.  Indian people were not allowed to vote until 1971,

By the time Indigenous people could effectively share in the bounty of the Confederation most of the wealth etc. had already been carved up and shared out to others.

Comment: I am sure we could tear everyone down without much effort, and every person memorialized with a statue or a day has warts.  That isn't the point--we celebrate them for the amazing things they did.  Do we reject MLK because he was unfaithful to his wife?  Should we pass on Lincoln because he only freed slaves in the unoccupied south--a calculated political move?  Our collective heritage of imperfect people doing amazing things, like Columbus leading the voyage of those three tiny ships into the unknown, should be celebrated, and still is all across North and South America.  I wish we spent more time finding heroes to inspire us to greatness rather than tearing everything down.

Comment: The cost is more than just "losing a feeling of justice"; it's also losing the feeling of being safe in your home and neighborhood and there's a financial cost too. Property crime costs the community in lots of ways. Stolen property costs the victims in more ways than one. First they lose their sense of security along with the use of what was stolen from them and then, if they were fortunate enough to have insurance on it, the insurance company depreciates the value of it before paying a claim. The victim has to pay the policy deductible and then accept whatever they can get from the insurance claim. In some cases the stolen items are irreplaceable. As insurance claims rise, so do premiums. And when property crime becomes a regular problem, then concentrated crime neighborhoods get a reputation. Property values drop as a result.  
We don't save anything by not incarcerating criminals. We just let the system ignore its duty and shift the cost burden to the residents.

In other words, licensing bicycles does not appear to be a practical or viable solution...

Comment: Census numbers are always both out of date and unreliable.

Because census numbers are based on self-reporting they are subject to errors that can't necessarily be adjusted for and even estimating the size of the error can be unreliable.  Certain groups are more or less likely to fill in their survey (even though they are legally required to do so only about 90 to 95% of the people sent the long-form survey actually fill it in) while other people either intentionally or accidentally falsify their data.

The regular income statistics, that come from personal income tax returns and/or tax fillings from employers, tend to be much more reliable than census data.  The main reason to use census data is to correlate two otherwise unrelated pieces of data that wouldn't normally be included in a single data set. Something like income level by language spoken at home.

Comment: Here are some reasons why I use YOC.  The total cost of a stock is the amount that I have at risk in that equity.  If the stock goes up or doubles, then the extra amount is invested elsewhere as are the dividends.  Hence I show the difference between the RIF's total book value and the market value because that profit is making more dividends on a constant basis by re-investment. The total cost of an equity is constant while the market value fluctuates constantly as the ticker goes by.

Comment: Some facts about  languages: 

Mandarin is the most spoken language in the world; however, English is the most widely spoken language ( note the difference) followed by Spanish.

In China, as in many countries, English is now a mandatory second language.

Chinese has about a dozen major variations with Mandarin the major variation ( Some people incorrectly call these variations " dialects"). The type of Mandarin spoken around Beijing is now the official language of China. And, those Chinese characters you see:, they are called "Hanzi". Even though the major types of the Chinese language are mutually incomprehensible to the listener,  the Hanzi  character set is understood by all people who speak  Chinese. That  is why they will  never disappear because these characters serve to unite the Chinese mainland. A Cantonese speaker won't understand a Hakka speaker, but they still can communicate using the Hanzi. Something like a Chinese Esperanto.

Comment: I don't want to over-argue the case concerning distinctions between our different rights and freedoms. Collectively they are the bedrock on which Canada's social contract stands. Eliminate any one of those rights and it's game over. So each right can be regarded as essential to our way of life.

On the other hand, our rights extend across very different aspects of what it means to be a Canadian citizen. So clearly the rights aren't equal in every way. Some of those rights, by their very nature, cannot be limited by government decree. The freedoms of conscience, thought, opinion and belief are- at least at present- untouchable by any authority. Our other fundamental freedoms- namely, religion, expression, peaceful assembly and association, can be limited by government. Nevertheless, any government that does so puts our entire way of life at risk.

Comment: Sure, women's national soccer teams regularly lose to U16 boys teams, so the quality of play is quite a bit lower than the highest men's standards at the moment, but that can also be said about every league in England below the Championship.

Look at League Two, the lowest pro league in England. Managers earn 50K, and the players earn 750 pounds a week, or roughly 65K Canadian a year. The top team in that league, Portsmouth FC, sees 15K in the stands every week, but most see half that, at best.

League Two is VERY comparable to the NSWL for attendance figures, actually.  The Portland Thorn see the most attendance in the NWSL, and get 15K a game, and the league average is just under the League 2 average.  The NWSL should be able to match that pay level, no? Sure, League Two has TV coverage the NWSL does not, but surely that's a problem with league marketing that can be fixed?

I think a market exists, but looking for a market as equally lucrative as the top men's leagues is a bit naïve.

Comment: Much is being made of an apparent statutory obligation to pay the PFD.  Many are demanding, and some litigating, to insure "we follow the PFD statute".   Well, doesn't that same body of statute direct that PFD payments are to be paid directly to individual Alaskans regardless of age?  The law doesn't direct payment to families or guardians of children.   Children don't have to apply for a PFD;however, if they do (even by proxy) those Children's dividends should be held in trust by the state until the child reaches the age of majority or the funds are otherwise released by court order.  Sometimes that PFD money is all a kid is going to have once he or she becomes an adult and he or she should receive the benefit for being an Alaskan resident just like the adults - living or dead.

Comment: Walt there are many ways to identify a military person driving the Alcan. Military members tend to have very squared away hair cuts; the short, close cut back of their heads for example. They tend to be in say the 23 to 45 years old age range. At most of the places you stop you'll hear them talking about where they are being transfer to.  

I'd say the best indicator would be to take a survey of the U-Haul locations.  That might result in a closer to reality count or military and not military travelers. OR ask real-estate brokers about available properties off base. 

Lots of the military go by ferry to or from  Belingham, WA. rather than having to cross into Canada with a firearm.  The past two summers the South and North bound ferries out of Whittier were all booked sold from late may to late August.

Comment: All you have to look at is table 3 (Revenues) and table 7 (Expenses) and you get the raw dollars, not figures relative to GDP, so you can easily see that there was more expenditures than revenues in every Mulroney year. 

And before you get into the notion of debt servicing crippling Mulroney... the cost of servicing the debt in the Expenses table balloons from 16.9Bn in 1982 to 41Bn by 1992, or from 17% of expenses to 28% of expenses. You don't see federal finances getting interest payments back down to the percentage of expenses they represented under Trudeau until 2004, in fact.

Comment: Part 5 (continued from earlier response)

Third premise to the model: human consciousness is quite limited.  Those who study the mind say that conscious attention can be given to about 5 to 7 things at one time.  In order to function, the conscious mind must selectively attend to a relatively small fraction of sensory and cognitive signals competing for attention.  As anyone who has taught their children how to drive will appreciate, it takes practice to acquire the skill to selectively attend to the information most important to handling a car on the road and in the stream of traffic.  Yet effective learning is acquired without conscious attention by what is called "implicit memory", which discerns patterns from experience.  Culture is transmitted from one generation to the next in this fashion.  Conscious attention is required to change patterns that have been absorbed by the processes of implicit memory.

See Part 6.

Comment: Classical capitalism (as articulated by Adam Smith) includes an element of socialism in that it recognizes the need for government to deliver services designed to meet the greater good.   That aspect of capitalism is often left aside or simply ignored.

It would be interesting to see what Smith would say about the huge role large corporations play in the private sector today and how that affects capitalist systems now.   I suspect he would have some reservations.   It's hard to know for sure since his work focused on individuals and smaller enterprises as large companies were not the force while he was alive that they are now.

Comment: Lets put the cards on the table ...

- Junior made electoral reform one of more than 200 promises for two reasons.  He thought the young low information voters who normally vote NDP would think this was cool and some would move to the Liberals (he was right). -  Neither the Liberals (who have benefited the most) nor the Conservatives (who have benefited as well) want to abandon FPTP for a PR system because such a system would lead to unstable minority goverments over 90% of the time. - So both of the major parties want this dumb, rash Trudeau promise to go away, at least until after 2019.

- For the NDP, the Greens, etc. it is a life line to many more seats.

Comment: Generally, citizen-initiated ballot measures are only voted on at general elections in November of even-numbered years.
BUT TABOR allows for tax or bonding issues to be voted on in odd-numbered years.
There is considerable debate among all sorts of groups whether to try an odd-numbered year ballot measure or wait for the next general election. Odd-numbered year ballot issues are sort of like special elections: Only the truly motivated show up. Whereas, in general elections, a much broader pool of people shows up. That plays different ways to different groups.
But! Colorado now has all-mail balloting which goes out to every registered voter, and that throws the standard political calculus right out the window.

Comment: Back in 92/95 living East of Missoula Montana on a small creek my fiancée with our 2 dogs. Living in a large A-frame cabin with no insulation at all, an outhouse, used creek water for most stuff an no plumbing an did have a sauna with a barrel stove for using a shower bag. I was home inside the 2 dogs, an both ran the window an were intensely looking at the creek 15 feet from the small porch. In the water was a Mink with a Muskrat in its mouth by its nec in a death roll in the large pool of trout water. The Muskrat was letting out a loud squeal while it  fought for its life. Cool place:  Big Horns fighting in back yard, Black bears on porch, Moose in back window, deer all over an yet the Mink & Muskrat was what I remember very well. But worst was the ever present damaging Pack Rats. Had to put rat traps under all tires each night or the PR would get up on the engines each night.

A lot of people thought 'solar roadways' was a great idea but if you happen to know the first thing about either roads or solar panels, you can see at first glance that it's not going to work.  It's slightly less apparent that wind & solar aren't going to work as sustainable replacements for fossil fuels on a large scale, but with EROIs in the low single digits it's a pretty safe bet.

Critique of Jacobson's 100% WWS plan in PNAS last week:

Comment: Lovely story. Wife and I are in exactly the same position with our cottage on the shores of lake Huron. I had a spinal decompression and fusion 4 years ago and am on the waiting list for a hip replacement. Athelene just had a knee replacement 4 weeks ago. Our three children all have busy lives in different cities and are visiting the cottage less and less. Even the grandchildren, growing into teenage years, are so busy in the summer that it is difficult for them to find time to visit.  Maintenance is slowly falling behind and the cedar hedge there is tall and wide enough that I almost need a helicopter to trim it. 
But we keep putting off the decision. Everything really depends on the results of the surgery. If we recover enough to keep up with the maintenance we will probably keep it a few more years. If not, we will sell. I agree with the author that the cottage means a great more to us than to the children. But one weekend with the grandchildren is enough to change our minds.

Comment: That’s distinctly different from ‘original gender’ for two reasons. First, sex and gender are not the same thing. Basically, gender is psychological (gender identity) and sex is anatomical (reproductive organs). For most people that distinction isn’t important because their gender identity matches their reproductive organs. But for transgender people the distinction between gender and sex is extremely important because their gender identity is different than their reproductive organs. The very definition of transgender requires you to distinguish between sex and gender. And the reason why this is especially important to your story is that as far as we know, a person’s gender identity is programmed in utero and remains fixed for their entire life [ see reference: Bao and Swaab, 2011]. So, for example, in the case of a transgender woman with male reproductive organs and a female gender identity, their ‘original gender’ would be female, but their ‘original sex’ would be male.

Comment: Your comment inspired me to dig up some comparative numbers (warning some data may be a few years old).  The University of Texas System has a $16.9 billion operating budget. Texas has a population of $25.1 million and 213,000 students in the system.  This works out to $673 per resident and a whopping $79,000 per student.  The UA system has an operating budget of $335 million. Alaska has a population of 737,000 and 34,000 students. This works out to $454 per resident and a miniscule $9,900 per student. Meanwhile the UA endowment is around $200 million ($271 per resident), while the UT endowment is $24.1 billion ($960 per resident).  The resident cost of attendance at UT is $26k/yr while the cost at UAA is $21k.  Given these numbers, I would conclude that UA has been extremely efficient with its comparatively small budget.  Moreover, I'd say the State of Alaska has been short-sighted in its relative lack of investment in the UA system.

Comment: Jenkins repeats the lie that "more than 90 million Americans are out of the workforce," pushed by  right-wing media. Politifact.com fact checks this claim.

"The total U.S. population age 16 and over is at least 243 million. Subtracting the nearly 156 million Americans in the labor force in June 2013 -- that is, those who were either working or looking for work -- leaves 87 million Americans, which is close to 90 million.

The 90 million number is padded, since this number includes a lot of Americans who wouldn’t be expected to be working. Specifically:

• People age 16 to 17, who likely are in high school: 9 million

• People who are enrolled in either two- or four-year colleges: 21 million

• People age 65 and older, who have reached retirement age: 40 million people

That means 20 million people are of normal working age, not in college and not working."

They rate this claim Mostly False, but Paul Jenkins, who always complains about media bias, pushes it anyways.
