Comment: Luther set off a storm that had been gathering for awhile.  He wasn't the first reformer in the Church, but he succeeded where others failed because of a blend of factors: the strength of his personality, the sharpness of his intellect [he was a biblical scholar], the strength of his personality, the quickness of his pen, the protection he was offered by the powerful Duke Frederick of Saxony, the passion of German Christians to end their subservience to the Italian churchmen---and the printing press .  

The printing press made it not only possible to read the Bible and Luther's ideas ---and it  not only assured that every Protestant home had a bible to read, but it became important that people were able TO READ.  More books to read were produced in Germany than were ever able to be produced before [because before the printing press,  books were written out by hand for only a few people].  The  very early concepts of universal education [males]  began at this time, in Germany.

Comment: There are factual errors in your post that require correction.

First, jail beds don't sit vacant because there's no money to hire staff.  The levy passed 4 years ago and renewed this month gives adequate funds to hire the staff to open the beds.  The problem is finding qualified applicants and getting them hired and certified.  The county is very picky (rightfully so) about who they hire for this job - far more selective than the city or state.

Second, the county didn't give away the forest work camp.  They rented it to the veterans group for a very nominal amount, this is true.  But the group is taking over all maintenance of the site, which was costing the county hundreds of thousands in tax dollars per year. Comment: Jerome Bruner demonstrated repeatedly that almost any concept can be taught in an age appropriate way.  Obviously the problem is deciding where to devote precious teaching time.  However, ignorance of math abounds in our country.  One way to address this is to integrate small bits into the curriculum very early on.  Regarding statistics, introducing concepts like variance or standard deviation would take far too long to be practical but, for example, a concept like "range" can be illustrated using the heights of the children in the class and even some foundation for the concept of "distribution" can be slipped in.  Concrete examples can bring abstract concepts to life even in kindergarten.  Many adults, unlike kids, have a phobia stemming from a barrage of math formulas dumped on them with no seeming connection to real life.  No wonder some adults tune out and underestimate both what good teachers can do and how math is relevant to life.

Comment: The only real solution in Health Care is to take the "health Care Insurance Industry" out of the equation. 
-
Have doctors and hospitals and other health care providers charge "real prices" up front, and not the "artificially jacked up prices" that scares people into buying "insurance" in order to get the "artificial discount on the artificially jacked up prices." 
-
Then have The Government provide Universal Health Care to everyone based on the "real prices" which are 70% - 80% (or more) of the "artificially jacked up prices".....which eliminates the entire Private Sector Health For-Profit Insurance Industry.....which saves money, and a lot of it.
-
Want proof? Say an operation costs, today, $10,000. Your "insurance" covers 80% and you pay 20% ($2,000). Does your insurance company pay $8,000 to the hospital? No, no where close. The "discount cost" is $3,000, which means you paid for insurance to cover $1,000 while you paid $2,000. 
-
It's not the "big bargain." It's a complete scam.

Comment: I don't know what the requirements are for a city to acquire an American Hockey League team and at this point I don't really care, but I feel I have to put this out there.

The ECHL is a development league.  That means the Aces can only have so many returning veterans and the remainder of the team must be rookies.  So the team is in constant flux.  Because of that, there is very little incentive for the casual fan to become a season ticket holder.    Fans want heros and because of the very nature of the ECHL that is impossible.

NHL players such as Ovechkin, Crosby, Tewes, etc all are long-term players of their respective teams.  Millions of dollars are spent on their jerseys.  They are heros because fans have to come expect to see them year after year.

Comment: What I love about living in Ketchikan for over 44 years is that we don't have neighborhoods where the "well to do" live and neighborhoods where the "not so well to do" live in the city. Almost every neighborhood in the city has a mix of homes, apartment complexes and schools. There are "stately" homes from the 1920's that grace streets next to other types of housing units.
The low income housing is built across the street from three schools and the recreation center. It is very well maintained with beautiful landscaping and if you didn't know it was for low income you would think it was a middle income apartment complex. Part of the "mix" of neighborhoods is due in part to the low income housing's voucher program that allows folks to rent anywhere the landlord will participate. 
We have the Pioneer Home across the street from a complex for low income seniors or disabled that is maintained wonderfully. It is next to a very nice Best Western Hotel. 
Outside the city things are a mix too.

Comment: Tim: you are making a lot of unsupported assumptions. You do not anything about me yet you suggest I am not being honest. Comment: When the storm hit a decade ago, I figured that if everything was going to a really hot place in a handbasket, it didn't matter where my money was.  And there were loads of preferred shares with dividend yields of 12% to 15%.

So while my co-workers were happily unloading their mutual funds and swearing they would never by anything riskier than a GIC ever again, I was happily loading up on preferred shares.

I've been a student of market history, and market history told me that markets go up and markets go down.  And because the markets had just gone down, odds were pretty good they were going to go back up.

If I could go back and make any changes, I would have picked up a few more common shares than I did.  Let's face it.  I didn't do badly with Royal Bank preferred shares.  But I would have done a lot better in Royal Bank common.  :)

Comment: Scott,

Two points:

1. I think you should provide a reference to the book from which you are drawing the quotation. It is "The Undoing Project" which chronicles the partnership of Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky who together pioneered research into many aspects of human decision making, perhaps most notably Prospect Theory.

2. It seems unusual to use a citation to K&T's work as a basis for supporting a passive Index Investing strategy which has the Efficient Markets Hypothesis as part of its rationale. K&T's stands in direct opposition to that hypothesis and is the basis upon which much of Behavioral Finance is built. K&T's work demonstrated that there are legitimate behavioural reasons why certain active investing strategies will provide higher than market returns. A number of factors have been clearly identified, some even by Eugene Fama, the originator of the EMH, himself.  Factor investing strategies are a legitimate alternative to index strategies that investors should consider

Comment: Here's the University of Chicago statement on Obama calling himself a professor: The Law School has received many media requests about Barack Obama, especially about his status as "Senior Lecturer." From 1992 until his election to the U.S. Senate in 2004, Barack Obama served as a professor in the Law School. He was a Lecturer from 1992 to 1996. He was a Senior Lecturer from 1996 to 2004, during which time he taught three courses per year. Senior Lecturers are considered to be members of the Law School faculty and are regarded as professors, although not full-time or tenure-track. The title of Senior Lecturer is distinct from the title of Lecturer, which signifies adjunct status. Like Obama, each of the Law School’s Senior Lecturers have high-demand careers in politics or public service, which prevent full-time teaching. Several times during his 12 years as a professor in the Law School, Obama was invited to join the faculty in a full-time tenure-track position, but he declined

These are not big economies that have important trade relationships with Canada, so it may not hurt the PBO projections much.
